slides.title: Introduction to Coverage Terms
slides.notes: Introduce the topic of coverage terms in PolicyCenter and its importance in configuring insurance products.
slides.narration: Welcome to our session on Coverage Terms within Guidewire PolicyCenter. Today, we'll explore how coverage terms are integral to defining insurance products. As developers, understanding these terms is crucial, as they shape how coverage is applied and managed. We'll dive into the data model, configurations, and practical examples to give you a solid foundation in working with these elements.
slides.ocrText: Coverage Terms

slides.title: The Role of Coverage Terms
slides.notes: Discuss the foundational role of coverage terms in insurance policies.
slides.narration: Coverage terms serve as the backbone of insurance policy configurations. They define the specifics of what a coverage includes, such as limits and deductibles. For developers, this means mapping these terms accurately in the data model to ensure that policies are correctly applied and rated.
slides.ocrText:
Lesson
objectives

• List examples of coverage terms
• Describe generic schedules

slides.title: Coverage Term Patterns
slides.notes: Explain coverage term patterns and their association with coverage patterns.
slides.narration: In PolicyCenter, coverage term patterns are the templates that guide how coverage terms are structured. Each coverage pattern is linked to a coverage term pattern, which then informs the creation of coverage term instances. This relationship is key to customizing insurance products and tailoring them to market needs.

slides.title: Examples of Coverage Patterns
slides.originalNotes:
Coverage terms
A coverage term pattern holds the configuration information for the terms of a coverage. Each coverage pattern has anassociated coverage term pattern. PolicyCenter uses the coverage term pattern to create coverage term instances for coverage instances.

Here are some examples of coverage patterns for zero, one or many terms attached.

Loss of Use coverage in the base commercial auto line is an example of a coverage pattern with no coverage termpatterns. After you add the coverage, the extent of thecoverage is the same for all policies.
Hired Auto Collision coverage in the base commercial auto line is an example of a coverage pattern with one term pattern. It has a deductible term, but no other terms, such as a limit.
The Employee Dishonesty coverage in the base businessowners line is an example of a coverage pattern with multiple coverage term patterns. It has terms for limit, number of covered employees, and number of covered locations.
slides.notes:
Coverage terms
A coverage term pattern holds the configuration information for the terms of a coverage. Each coverage pattern has anassociated coverage term pattern. PolicyCenter uses the coverage term pattern to create coverage term instances for coverage instances.

Here are some examples of coverage patterns for zero, one or many terms attached.

Loss of Use coverage in the base commercial auto line is an example of a coverage pattern with no coverage termpatterns. After you add the coverage, the extent of thecoverage is the same for all policies.
Hired Auto Collision coverage in the base commercial auto line is an example of a coverage pattern with one term pattern. It has a deductible term, but no other terms, such as a limit.
The Employee Dishonesty coverage in the base businessowners line is an example of a coverage pattern with multiple coverage term patterns. It has terms for limit, number of covered employees, and number of covered locations.
slides.narration: Now, let’s look at some examples. For instance, Loss of Use coverage doesn't have any coverage term patterns. It remains consistent across policies. Hired Auto Collision, with a single deductible term, and Employee Dishonesty coverage with multiple terms, show the flexibility and granularity we can achieve in PolicyCenter. This allows us to cater to diverse business requirements.

slides.title: Attributes of Coverage Terms
slides.originalNotes:
Coverage term attributes
For configuration, the options for the term type are listed in Product Designer. These options control the look and usability of the widget in the user interface.

The model type is what the term value measures. A coverage term's behavior on the user interface is the same regardless of the value for model type. However, this value has implications when the value ispassed to the rating engine, and when a policy is imported into PolicyCenter.
slides.notes:
Coverage term attributes
For configuration, the options for the term type are listed in Product Designer. These options control the look and usability of the widget in the user interface.

The model type is what the term value measures. A coverage term's behavior on the user interface is the same regardless of the value for model type. However, this value has implications when the value ispassed to the rating engine, and when a policy is imported into PolicyCenter.
slides.narration: Coverage terms have specific attributes like term type and model type. These attributes are configured in the Product Designer and influence how terms appear in the UI and interact with the rating engine. Understanding these attributes is vital for ensuring that terms behave correctly across policy lifecycle stages.

slides.title: Data Model: Coverage Tables and Terms
slides.originalNotes:
Coverage tables and coverage terms
For better performance, coverage terms are not stored in separate table. They are stored as columns in each coverage table. The coverage table defines the data entity that contains the coverages. Each type of coverage is applied to a coverable and coverage table.
slides.notes:
Coverage tables and coverage terms
For better performance, coverage terms are not stored in separate table. They are stored as columns in each coverage table. The coverage table defines the data entity that contains the coverages. Each type of coverage is applied to a coverable and coverage table.
slides.narration: For efficiency, coverage terms are stored as columns within coverage tables rather than separate entities. This improves performance while maintaining the relational integrity of our data model. Each coverage type is linked to a coverable entity, ensuring that terms are tightly integrated with the policy structure.
slides.ocrText:
| Coverage tables and coverage terms

Coverage table

Dwelling

slides.title: Managing Coverage Term Columns
slides.originalNotes:
Coverage term columns
Configuration developers need to know that there are several different types of coverage terms, each with a different datatype. For example, direct coverage terms are stored as decimal. Choice coverage terms, which includes option, package, and typekey, are stored as pattem codes- The Generic term type is stored based on their data type.

Every coverage table has a set number of columns for each type of coverage term. For example, the CP Building coverage table, CPBuildingCov.eti, has three columns for direct coverage terms- When creating a coverage term pattern for a coverage pattern, specify the column where the coverage term values will be stored. For example, when creating a direct coverage term pattern for a CP Building coverage pattem, specify if the value for the coverage term (not the pattern) is stored in the first direct coverage term column or the second direct coverage term column- Standard columns in the data dictionary are also visible in the table.

For a single coverage, if the number of coverage terms of one type is more than the number of table columns available for that coverage term type, then extend the coverage table and add an additional column. For example, if a given CP building coverage needs four direct coverage terms, but there is no fourth column available so extend the table and add a new column for the fourth direct coverage term.
Finally,
define Generic coverage term types as custom values which must be a string, date andtime, or Boolean value. A date and time value isformatted as yyyy-MM- dd HH:mm:ss.SSS. Although you can use generic coverage terms for numeric values, Guidewire recommends that you use direct coverage terms instead.
slides.notes:
Coverage term columns
Configuration developers need to know that there are several different types of coverage terms, each with a different datatype. For example, direct coverage terms are stored as decimal. Choice coverage terms, which includes option, package, and typekey, are stored as pattem codes- The Generic term type is stored based on their data type.

Every coverage table has a set number of columns for each type of coverage term. For example, the CP Building coverage table, CPBuildingCov.eti, has three columns for direct coverage terms- When creating a coverage term pattern for a coverage pattern, specify the column where the coverage term values will be stored. For example, when creating a direct coverage term pattern for a CP Building coverage pattem, specify if the value for the coverage term (not the pattern) is stored in the first direct coverage term column or the second direct coverage term column- Standard columns in the data dictionary are also visible in the table.

For a single coverage, if the number of coverage terms of one type is more than the number of table columns available for that coverage term type, then extend the coverage table and add an additional column. For example, if a given CP building coverage needs four direct coverage terms, but there is no fourth column available so extend the table and add a new column for the fourth direct coverage term.
Finally,
define Generic coverage term types as custom values which must be a string, date andtime, or Boolean value. A date and time value isformatted as yyyy-MM- dd HH:mm:ss.SSS. Although you can use generic coverage terms for numeric values, Guidewire recommends that you use direct coverage terms instead.
slides.narration: Developers need to be aware of how coverage term columns are managed. With various data types like decimal for direct terms and pattern codes for choice terms, it’s crucial to configure columns correctly. If more terms are needed than columns available, you’ll need to extend the table — a common customization to accommodate complex policies.

slides.title: Mapping Terms to Data Columns
slides.originalNotes:
Mapping coverage terms to columns
To map coverage terms to the table columns in the product model, use Product Designer to specify the column of the coverage table. The coverage term values are stored in PolicyCenter database in the specified column of the coverage table.
slides.notes:
Mapping coverage terms to columns
To map coverage terms to the table columns in the product model, use Product Designer to specify the column of the coverage table. The coverage term values are stored in PolicyCenter database in the specified column of the coverage table.
slides.narration: Mapping coverage terms to their respective columns is done in Product Designer. This step is critical to ensure that terms are stored and retrieved correctly from the PolicyCenter database. This mapping helps maintain data consistency and supports accurate policy processing and reporting.

slides.title: UI and User Experience
slides.notes: Discuss how coverage terms impact the user interface and user experience.
slides.narration: The configuration of coverage terms directly affects the user interface and user experience in PolicyCenter. By selecting appropriate term types and attributes, we can streamline the UI, making it intuitive for users to navigate and understand policy details. This alignment between backend configuration and frontend presentation is key to user satisfaction.

slides.title: Integration with Rating Engine
slides.notes: Explain how coverage terms interact with the rating engine.
slides.narration: Coverage terms play a significant role in how policies are rated. When these terms are passed to the rating engine, their attributes and values influence the premium calculations. Understanding this relationship helps us ensure accurate pricing and compliance with underwriting guidelines.

slides.title: Advanced Configuration Scenarios
slides.notes: Explore advanced scenarios involving coverage terms.
slides.narration: In more advanced scenarios, you might need to customize coverage terms to meet unique business needs. This could involve creating new term patterns or extending existing ones. Such configurations require a deep understanding of the data model and the product design framework to ensure they integrate seamlessly with existing systems.

slides.title: Generic Schedules Overview
slides.originalNotes:
Generic Schedules
Generic schedules are instances of schedules that are implemented by using the genericschedule data model. The schedules interact with a common set of Gosu classes, PCF pages, and entity interfaces. The generic schedule data model includes one set of entity types that have many columns. These columns are not inherently descriptive, but instead provide a generic way to store information. When configuring a new schedule, you use these generic columns and provide a description for them in the context of the schedule.

Note: The old generic schedule class still works, but it is now deprecated.
slides.notes:
Generic Schedules
Generic schedules are instances of schedules that are implemented by using the genericschedule data model. The schedules interact with a common set of Gosu classes, PCF pages, and entity interfaces. The generic schedule data model includes one set of entity types that have many columns. These columns are not inherently descriptive, but instead provide a generic way to store information. When configuring a new schedule, you use these generic columns and provide a description for them in the context of the schedule.

Note: The old generic schedule class still works, but it is now deprecated.
slides.narration: Generic schedules offer a flexible way to manage scheduled items in PolicyCenter. These schedules are backed by a robust data model and leverage common Gosu classes and PCF pages. While the old generic schedule class is deprecated, understanding its structure helps when migrating to or implementing new schedules.
slides.ocrText:
Generic Schedules

• Schedules are lists of detailed information about an
insured’s coverables

« Examples
+ Personal property in a homeowner's policy
+ Authorized workers in a workers’ compensation policy
* Generic schedules

« Use the generic schedule data model that stores information
in a generic way

* Can be easily created and edited using Product Designer

* Can be declaratively defined in product model XML files

slides.title: Implementing Schedules in Lines of Business
slides.originalNotes:
Types of schedules
Scheduled items are the individual rows of a schedule.

In the base configuration, the following lines use generic schedules:
1) The Homeowners line includes both schedules and schedules with coverage terms. Implemented using product model XML and generic schedule data model. Use homeowners as a model for adding generic schedules in other lines of business.
2) The General liability line includes schedules. It is implemented using generic schedule data model but does not use product model XML. Do not use this as a model for adding generic schedules in other lines of business.
slides.notes:
Types of schedules
Scheduled items are the individual rows of a schedule.

In the base configuration, the following lines use generic schedules:
1) The Homeowners line includes both schedules and schedules with coverage terms. Implemented using product model XML and generic schedule data model. Use homeowners as a model for adding generic schedules in other lines of business.
2) The General liability line includes schedules. It is implemented using generic schedule data model but does not use product model XML. Do not use this as a model for adding generic schedules in other lines of business.
slides.narration: Different lines of business utilize generic schedules in varied ways. For instance, Homeowners use both schedules and coverage terms, offering a comprehensive model for implementation. In contrast, General Liability uses schedules without product model XML. These examples highlight the adaptability of schedules to cater to line-specific needs.
slides.ocrText:
| Types of schedules

slides.title: Steps for Adding Generic Schedules
slides.originalNotes:
Steps to add generic schedules to a line of business
In Product Designer, add schedules to clauses including coverages, conditions and exclusions. This is illustrated in more details on the next slide.
slides.notes:
Steps to add generic schedules to a line of business
In Product Designer, add schedules to clauses including coverages, conditions and exclusions. This is illustrated in more details on the next slide.
slides.narration: To add generic schedules to a line of business, you start by incorporating them into clauses like coverages, conditions, and exclusions using Product Designer. This process is pivotal for ensuring that schedules are correctly integrated into policy structures, and we'll explore these steps in more detail shortly.
slides.ocrText:
| Steps to add generic schedules to a line of business [Fj

* Create Generic Schedule Data Model for the line

* Configure scheduled clauses and properties in the product model, using Product
Designer

* (Optional) Configure the schedule user interface if you want to change how it looks
and operates

slides.title: Configuring Schedules in Product Designer
slides.originalNotes:
Configure generic schedules in Product Designer
If the schedules do not have coverage terms, you only need to add a coverage for the schedules and configure the schedule properties for the scheduled items.

The same steps of adding the scheduled coverages apply to conditions and exclusions.
slides.notes:
Configure generic schedules in Product Designer
If the schedules do not have coverage terms, you only need to add a coverage for the schedules and configure the schedule properties for the scheduled items.

The same steps of adding the scheduled coverages apply to conditions and exclusions.
slides.narration: When configuring schedules without coverage terms, the focus is on adding the schedule itself and setting properties for scheduled items. This straightforward process involves defining the schedule’s attributes and ensuring they align with policy requirements, which is essential for maintaining data integrity and operational efficiency.

slides.title: Schedules with Coverage Terms
slides.originalNotes:
Configure generic schedules in Product Designer
It is optional to add the scheduled item coverages for schedules with coverage terms.

In the Homeowners policy line,
Scheduled Personal Property(HOPScheduledPers onalProperty) is the schedule coverage that contains definitions of schedule properties for the scheduled items. It also has a link to the scheduled item coverage.
Scheduled Personal Property Item (HOPScheduledPersonalProp ertyltem) is the scheduled item coverage used to capture the limit, deductible for each item.

For more details about Generic Schedule Data Model and the user interface, refer to thePolicyCenter Configuration Guide.
slides.notes:
Configure generic schedules in Product Designer
It is optional to add the scheduled item coverages for schedules with coverage terms.

In the Homeowners policy line,
Scheduled Personal Property(HOPScheduledPers onalProperty) is the schedule coverage that contains definitions of schedule properties for the scheduled items. It also has a link to the scheduled item coverage.
Scheduled Personal Property Item (HOPScheduledPersonalProp ertyltem) is the scheduled item coverage used to capture the limit, deductible for each item.

For more details about Generic Schedule Data Model and the user interface, refer to thePolicyCenter Configuration Guide.
slides.narration: For schedules that include coverage terms, additional configurations might be necessary. In Homeowners policies, the Scheduled Personal Property illustrates how schedule coverages and item coverages are linked. These setups require careful configuration to ensure limits and deductibles are accurately captured and reflected in the policy.

slides.title: Exploring Schedule Data Models
slides.notes: Examine the underlying data models for schedules.
slides.narration: Understanding the data models that support schedules is vital. These models include entities and fields that may seem generic but serve as the foundation for storing schedule-related data. Familiarity with these models ensures that schedules are implemented effectively and that they can be extended or modified as business needs evolve.

slides.title: Demo: Configuring Coverage Terms
slides.notes: Guide the viewer through a demo on configuring coverage terms.
slides.narration: In this demo, observe how to configure coverage terms using Product Designer. Pay attention to how term patterns are assigned and mapped to data columns. This hands-on experience will reinforce your understanding of the configuration process and its impact on policy administration.

slides.title: UI Customization for Coverage Terms
slides.notes: Discuss customizing the UI for coverage terms.
slides.narration: Customizing the UI for coverage terms is about enhancing user interaction. By configuring PCF files, we can adjust how terms are displayed and interacted with, ensuring that users have a seamless experience. This customization is key to aligning the UI with backend configurations and user expectations.

slides.title: Best Practices for Term Configuration
slides.notes: Highlight best practices for configuring coverage terms.
slides.narration: Adhering to best practices in term configuration ensures reliability and performance. This includes consistently using direct terms for numeric values and carefully mapping terms to appropriate columns. Such practices help maintain system integrity and facilitate smooth policy operations.

slides.title: Troubleshooting Common Issues
slides.notes: Identify and resolve common issues with coverage terms.
slides.narration: When working with coverage terms, common issues may arise, such as incorrect data mapping or UI inconsistencies. Understanding how to troubleshoot these problems is essential. This involves checking configurations, validating data models, and ensuring all mappings align with business rules.

slides.title: Summary and Next Steps
slides.notes: Summarize key points and preview the next lesson on Product Model Availability.
slides.narration: In summary, coverage terms are a fundamental part of policy configurations in PolicyCenter, influencing everything from data storage to UI presentation. As you continue to build on this knowledge, our next lesson will delve into Product Model Availability, where we'll explore how products are configured and made available to users. Stay tuned for more insights into optimizing your PolicyCenter implementation.
